Reading Pauline Kael and @JessHopp lately, marveling at the potent sentences, wondering whose powerful sentences instructed and inspired them as they each began to build their custom writer’s toolkit. Eg., this movie criticism from Kael. Start at 0:50. https://t.co/d9hzQSk1u3

It’s an information access problem. I’d say that @SBTOutdoors posts TWO valuable kinds of information for people who treasure the things of nature in our region. First, there are very interesting ways to learn and participate _right now_, like this seed-growing example. And… https://t.co/9ZotzIH8pY
Second, @SBTOutdoors posts excellent introductions to long-term opportunities, like this new-to-many-of-us nature preserve an hour up the shore from here. Two kinds of truly valuable postings for real readers in our region. But then… https://t.co/XZpphMsppG
On social media, these excellent postings about life in our region are mixed together, and then slip down the screen into the archive. Unless you know to look for a particular posting, a reader can really only wander from screen to screen, an ineffective search method. And…
If you look for the two kinds of valuable @SBTOutdoors postings (immediate interest, enduring interest) at the @SBTribune website, they are (I’d say) blurred together with each other and also with all the “Lifestyle” articles. Search only helps if you know what’s there. So…
So, it’s an information access problem.
The @SBTOutdoors writer performs two kinds of valuable work, and the web publishing tools employed by the newspaper chain are not tuned finely enough to preserve and foreground both the real short and long-term value there. In conclusion…
Somebody should the newspaper chain’s stockholders they’re missing out on a chance to develop and exploit their product’s real social and economic value.

1/5 Dad worked for the natural gas company. Once in a while I’d hear him talk about a number called degree days, which comes from a formula that includes the mean monthly temperature.
2/5 The number of degree days for the town every March for the last decade gives a clue to how much gas the company should have on hand to sell next March.
3/5 But they’d need an extra, buffer supply of gas, because next March might be colder than other recent years. Each March has its own unpredictable degree day total, when all is said and done.
4/5 Our local natural gas company stored gas reserves in a porous layer of rock beneath the north side of the metro area. Buy it cheap in the summer, pump it underground, and pump it out later when it's needed.
5/5 Folks want their houses at 65 F. If the average March temperature is 40, that’s thirty days with a 25 degree heating load. If the average temperature is 15, that’s thirty days with a 50 degree heating load. We start to see why the gas company thinks in terms of degree days.
The National Weather Service explains the actual calculation of degree days for both cooling and heating.
